Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation2: A critical piece of equipment is issuing warning alerts that could lead to hazardous leakage.
Story:
I was just finishing up some data analysis in the lab when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old college acquaintance who’d recently moved to town. “Hey! Any chance you could recommend a good restaurant nearby? I’ve got family visiting and want to impress them.” I glanced at the message, feeling the familiar tug of social obligation. Mark had always been friendly, and I knew he’d appreciate a thoughtful suggestion.

But just as I started typing a reply, a shrill alarm blared from the other side of the lab. The gas chromatograph was flashing red—an equipment warning I couldn’t ignore. My heart pounded. If I didn’t act fast, there could be a hazardous leak, putting everyone in the building at risk. I was the only scientist on duty, responsible for safety and maintenance. Yet, Mark’s message lingered on my screen, a simple request for help that suddenly felt impossibly complicated. I stood frozen, torn between the expectation to be a supportive acquaintance and my duty to ensure the lab’s safety, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
